question: A three year old child is brought to the emergency depament having just ingested a large overdose of an antihistaminic drug. This drug is a weak base capable of entering most tissues including the brain. On physical examination the hea rate is 100/ minute, blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg and the respiratory rate is 20/ minute. In this case of poisoning:

options.opa: Urinary excretion would be accelerated by administration of NH4Cl, an acidifying agent
options.opb: Urinary excretion would be accelerated by administration of NaHCO 3, an alkalinizing agent
options.opc: More of the drug would be ionized at blood pH than at stomach pH
options.opd: Absorption of the drug would be faster from the stomach than from the small intestine.

reasoning_chain: CHAIN: "Antihistaminic drug is a weak base" -> "Weak bases are more ionized in acidic environments" -> "NH4Cl acidifies the urine" -> "More of the drug becomes ionized in acidic urine" -> "Ionized drugs are less likely to be reabsorbed in the renal tubules" -> "Increased urinary excretion of the drug" -> 85%

CHAIN: "Antihistaminic drug is a weak base" -> "Weak bases are less ionized in basic environments" -> "NaHCO3 alkalinizes the urine" -> "Less of the drug becomes ionized in alkaline urine" -> "Ionized drugs are more likely to be reabsorbed in the renal tubules" -> "Decreased urinary excretion of the drug" -> 85%

CHAIN: "Blood pH is approximately 7.4" -> "Stomach pH is approximately 1.5 to 3.5" -> "Weak bases are more ionized in acidic environments" -> "More of the drug would be ionized at stomach pH than at blood pH" -> 90%

CHAIN: "Absorption of drugs depends on surface area available for absorption" -> "The small intestine has a larger surface area compared to the stomach" -> "The small intestine has a more neutral pH favorable for absorption of weak bases" -> "Absorption of the drug would be faster from the small intestine than from the stomach" -> 90%
enhanced_information: In cases of antihistaminic drug overdose, urinary excretion can be accelerated by acidifying the urine with NH4Cl, as this increases the ionization of the weak base drug, reducing its reabsorption. Conversely, alkalinizing the urine with NaHCO3 would decrease excretion by reducing drug ionization. The drug is more ionized in the acidic stomach than in the alkaline blood, affecting its initial absorption. Absorption is generally faster in the small intestine due to its larger surface area and more neutral pH, which is more conducive for the absorption of weak bases.
analysis: The administration of NH4Cl, an acidifying agent, is supported by the pharmacological principle that acidifying the urine increases the ionization of weak base drugs, enhancing their excretion. This is the most effective method to accelerate the urinary excretion of a weak base antihistaminic drug in an overdose scenario.
